subject: Modify entityPrivileges for certificate service
commitMessage:
Modify entityPrivileges for certificate service

DMTF published new entity privileges for certificate service classes
which modify entity privilege Certificate, CertificateCollection,
CertificateLocations, and CertificateService on bmcweb. Modification
restricts a user without "ConfigureManager" from accessing the
CertificateCollection and Certificate scehamas

Redfish is a hypermedia API where the parent URI describes sub-URI.
Thus, restricting sub-URI in a parent-URI data helps to forbidden user
access, stricken the rule.  So sub-URI only gets display if a user has
access to that URI.

Restricting the link allows the Redfish Validator to pass.

These impact roles without ConfigureManager, which include operator
and read-only. No access is not impacted since it already did not
have access.

The following are bmcweb user consequences:
1. ReadOnly and Operator role users are no longer able to view
   certificates or the certificate collection (LDAP, HTTPS, TrustStore)
2. Operator role users are no longer able to replace the certificates
   (LDAP, HTTPS, TrustStore), Install certificates (LDAP, HTTPS,
   TrustStore) or delete the Truststore Certificate. HTTPS and LDAP
   certificates do not have delete methods.

Resolves openbmc/bmcweb#61

Tested: manually tested on Witherspoon system and run Redfish-Service-
Validator with all roles root, operator, read-only, and No access. Test
pass for root, operator, and read-only roles, And new errors get
introduced for no access role.

Signed-off-by: Abhishek Patel <Abhishek.Patel@ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ibc5eed7db7e224e46f8572df8bcfba2a1ff47644

My current intent is to get the Node removal series merged;  Then we can discuss this one, as I suspect there's going to be some discussions we'll need to have.  If you'd like, feel free to rebase your commit AFTER that change if you don't want to wait for it, but we need to figure out a solution that doesn't involve the Node class.

Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)

Overall, this is the first thing that's starting to change the Redfish GET tree itself dependent on what user is present (well, technically there was AccountService, but that was better defined).  To some extent, I'm going to be making sure this is a pattern we can follow into the future without a ton of boilerplate.

To some extent, I'm really wishing we had a "Resource" model that we could attach permissions to like sailfish did, instead of a per-handler model, but that's a lot of work to do, for not a ton of benefit at this point.

Patch Set 12:

Because you seem to have a vested interest in this, could you help to review this RFC?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939

It's trying to solve this problem more permanently.

Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 is a long term solution. 
I think this could go and https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 could go later but also fine if we think 43939 can go here soon and this can just be abandoned.

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1
> 
> https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 is a long term solution. 
> I think this could go and https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 could go later but also fine if we think 43939 can go here soon and this can just be abandoned.

My problem here is that we're changing behavior.  43939 for the moment just adds comments on the things that are "wrong", but we need to assess whether or not we need backward compatibility.  There are real things that are chaning in this patch, namely that operators can no longer replace certificates, which the impacts of which we should understand before this merges.

FWIW, I think 43939 is ready for a full review.  How many things people find will determine how ready it is to hit master.

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> > Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1
> > 
> > https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 is a long term solution. 
> > I think this could go and https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 could go later but also fine if we think 43939 can go here soon and this can just be abandoned.
> 
> My problem here is that we're changing behavior.  43939 for the moment just adds comments on the things that are "wrong", but we need to assess whether or not we need backward compatibility.  There are real things that are chaning in this patch, namely that operators can no longer replace certificates, which the impacts of which we should understand before this merges.
> 
> FWIW, I think 43939 is ready for a full review.  How many things people find will determine how ready it is to hit master.

How do you recommend we fix this then? A compile flag? Seems overkill... Can we send something to the mailing list?

I don't know of many openbmc users using the operator role and restricting an API to higher permission users doesn't feel like a break to me. 

With the current 43939, we still have this problem (we differ from the Redfish permissions). 
The Redfish permissions make sense. An operator shouldn't be allowed to replace a certificate.  (theoretically) Could an operator use replacing the certificate to do a permission escalation attack?

I vote we fix this and other places that differ from the Redfish permissions (if we differ for a good reason, I am okay with keeping that but the ones I have found just feel like mistakes).

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> > Patch Set 12:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1
> > > 
> > > https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 is a long term solution. 
> > > I think this could go and https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43939 could go later but also fine if we think 43939 can go here soon and this can just be abandoned.
> > 
> > My problem here is that we're changing behavior.  43939 for the moment just adds comments on the things that are "wrong", but we need to assess whether or not we need backward compatibility.  There are real things that are chaning in this patch, namely that operators can no longer replace certificates, which the impacts of which we should understand before this merges.
> > 
> > FWIW, I think 43939 is ready for a full review.  How many things people find will determine how ready it is to hit master.
> 
> How do you recommend we fix this then? A compile flag? Seems overkill... Can we send something to the mailing list?

I think it depends heavily on the impact, which I don't really see a statement of.  Technically the only change in behavior would be for Operator level users, and if we can verify that there's no way you could've had a real impact to working code, I'm ok with this change not having a flag.  If there's a possibility there's an impact to working code, I might still be ok with it, but I want to at least have an understanding documented so that when and if the bug comes in, we'll have something to point to for why we did this.

> 
> I don't know of many openbmc users using the operator role and restricting an API to higher permission users doesn't feel like a break to me. 

They're out there, and there are definitely people testing this stuff;  I'm a little surprised we didn't get this bug filed earlier, but I guess anyone coding against the standard wouldn't have noticed it.

> 
> With the current 43939, we still have this problem (we differ from the Redfish permissions). 
> The Redfish permissions make sense. An operator shouldn't be allowed to replace a certificate.  (theoretically) Could an operator use replacing the certificate to do a permission escalation attack?

not sure.

> 
> I vote we fix this and other places that differ from the Redfish permissions (if we differ for a good reason, I am okay with keeping that but the ones I have found just feel like mistakes).

I'm ok with that, but lets make sure we:
1. Have a permanent solution so we don't keep hitting this.  (I think my privileges commit is this)
2. have documented the impact when we change things that might have user facing consequences.
Uploaded patch set 13: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 720487803a1890e8d4e5d91463e7ec62b4b23f74 by Gunnar Mills

We should follow PrivilegeRegistry here. 
If we have a odata.id that a role doesn't have permission to GET, we should not display the link (I think what you do below?) for that role. 
I.e. if /redfish/v1/AccountService/LDAP/Certificates is something only ConfigureManager can access then only display when the user has permissions ConfigureManager

Why AllowedWithoutConfigureSelf? 
Should this be instead "does role have ConfigureManager" ?
And it passed? No new errors were introduced?

That's great, but doesn't really describe the change you made.  Considering you're changing the API surface, we need to be more clear about what changes you made, why you made them, and what the expected compatibility is.

nitpick: odd capitalization 
"Check if user has ConfigureManager privilege"?
Nitpick: True if user has ConfigureManager privilege ?
FYI, this class is going away, you will need to find another place to put this code.

Where is isAllowedWithoutConfigureSelf going? This should follow. 
A role_utils.cpp ?
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/tree/master/redfish-core/include/utils

Directly into the account service implementation, and comparing against a const variable in the same file instead of the class implementation.

No, this code shouldn't go in the same place.


The real issue this patchset is pushing at is that individual properties have permissions, which we in no way modeled in the code;  We'll need to have a generalized solution for that, rather than just adding what I suspect is a lot of code to each property to check against a given privilege.

Also, this will need to be compatible for when custom privilege registries are allowed, which further complicates this.

Redfish ? DMTF Redfish? have an extra space in there too.
E.g. "Redfish is a hypermedia API where ..." ?

Jenkins doesn't matter here, you could run the Redfish Validator from a lot of places. 
E.g. "Restricting the link allows the Redfish Validator to pass." ?

Can you add a sentence about which roles this impacts? 
E.g. "This impacts roles without ConfigureManager, which include operator and read-only. No access is not impacted since it already did not have access" ?

Which one? ;) 
E.g. "Test passed for root, operator, and read-only roles? And new errors for no access role"?
Redfish service validator alone isn't a sufficient test, as it has no concept of permissions or views.  You need to verify that for the privilege classes you expect, the tree looks correct.

I think this is a mistake adding. 
We should not be adding this back.
Please don't capture req here by reference, as it could lead to lifetime issues.  Put the code on line 202 in the preceeding scope, and capture effectiveUserPrivileges.

restricts a user without "ConfigureManager"? 
restricts a user without "ConfigureManager" from accessing the CertificateCollection and Certificate scehamas?
What about these? ConfigureManager permission is needed, should these also be in the if?

It does not appear as a hyperlink in my browser, and even validator is not looking for that.
So in the future, we are gone used it as a hyperlink, then I will restrict that code.

Can you add something about the user facing consequences like Ed mentioned? 
E.g. (I just roughly looked, please make sure these are correct)

The following are bmcweb user consequences: 
1. ReadOnly and Operator role users are no longer able to view certificates or the certificate collection (LDAP, HTTPS, TrustStore)
2. Operator role users are no longer able to replace the certificates (LDAP, HTTPS, TrustStore), Install certificates (LDAP, HTTPS, TrustStore) or delete the Truststore Certificate. HTTPS and LDAP certificates do not have delete methods.
